abstract: Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former Treasury Secretary, on Thursday contradicted an assertion by a former top executive of Bear Stearns that the firm was solvent when it was forced to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase, calling it an “almost a ridiculous statement.”
snippet: Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former Treasury Secretary, on Thursday contradicted an assertion by a former top executive of Bear Stearns that the firm was solvent when it was forced to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase, calling it an “almost a ridiculous ...
lead_paragraph: Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former Treasury Secretary, on Thursday contradicted an assertion by a former top executive of Bear Stearns that the firm was solvent when it was forced to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase, calling it an “almost a ridiculous statement.” Mr. Paulson insisted that Bear Stearns was out of cash and set to go under in March 2008, forcing it to seek a merger partner for survival.

headline.main: Paulson Rejects Claim That Bear Was Solvent

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Federal Reserve Bank of New York

abstract: A crisis for Toyota has become a catalyst for regulatory change with support from the White House, both political parties and the industry.
snippet: A crisis for Toyota has become a catalyst for regulatory change with support from the White House, both political parties and the industry.
lead_paragraph: In the new world of auto regulation, cars could be required to have “black boxes” to record crash data and be able to stop even with the engine at full power. Automakers could be ordered to recall defective vehicles immediately and pay safety fees to cover the costs of federal oversight.

headline.main: In Washington, a Renewed Taste for Auto Safety
headline.print_headline: In Washington, A New Appetite For Car Safety
